OK, I can't seem to let this go. It would be really, really hard for anyone to have average egress data of just 430KB per day. Just booting an iPhone would generate more outgoing data than that. Yes, you might boot into airplane mode or in a faraday cage, but then:

1/n pic.twitter.com/3kc5PLCDnA

(1) how do you upload any data at all over cellular and (2) how is that "fairly typical of an iPhone"?

I can't help thinking that there's an error in this carefully documented 430KB-per-day baseline. Did the FTI analysts make a mistake, or is there another explanation?

2/n

Based on the amount of data reported to egress Bezos' phone after receiving the WhatsApp message, there's no denying there were spikes as high as 300 fold. That's certainly suspicious. But if analysts erred in calculating the baseline, why should we trust the spike either?

3/n pic.twitter.com/cEFD9

What's more, Figure 13, from tweet 3/n indicates that, with the exception of a handful of days, the Bezos iPhone largely stuck to the baseline over the 9 months following receipt of the WhatsApp message. Fig. 14 shows that the truly massive spikes didn't start until 4/24/19.

4/n
Yeah, but Spotify accounts for incoming data, not egress (or outgoing) usage, correct?
Interesting. The stats I checked showed that just rebooting an iPhone caused "System Services" to eat 2 MB of data. "Time & Location" used 497KB. I wonder what's causing the difference.

I'm assuming data usage includes download as well. But by my calculation, 430KB/day is ~13MB/month. Assuming Bezos has a 1GB data plan (I'd guess it's more), his egress would be about 1% of the allotted amount. That seems like an unrealistic ratio of in to out.
I think we both know Kim and Joseph well enough to be confident they wouldn't include a marketing brochure in their copy.
13MB is ~1% of 1GB, no? (Honest question. I'm terrible at calculating file sizes.)

(1) Thanks for the explanation.

(2) It's fine for the authors to withhold a client's use of a secured iPhone. It's not OK for them to misrepresent a secured iPhone as a typical one.
I picked 1GB because I can't imagine Bezos having a data plan that isn't at least that large.
OK, so maybe Bezos didn't reboot his iPhone X for more than a year.
I was making a bunch of low-ball assumptions that I hoped would demonstrate how tiny 13MB/month of egress data is for anything approaching typical for an iPhone. I failed. :(
OK, so 13MB is 10% of 1GB?

I've always thought it's clearer to convert percentages above 100 to multiples, e.g. a 100% increase becomes a doubling, a 200% increase is a three-fold increase, and so on. A 29,156% increase is too opaque to be useful to average readers.
